item.title: Bodmin Moor Loop
item.description:
Bodmin Moor Loop

Distance: 35 miles | Type: Road

A spectacular but demanding circular route across Bodmin Moor, Cornwall’s granite upland. This ride features significant climbing, exposed moorland roads, and stunning panoramic views. Best suited to experienced cyclists with good fitness.

Route Overview

Starting from Waterloo Farm, the route heads onto Bodmin Moor via quiet lanes, climbing steadily to cross the high moorland plateau. The route passes iconic moorland landmarks including Brown Willy (Cornwall’s highest point), Rough Tor, and dramatic granite tors.

item.title: Colliford Lake
item.description:
Colliford Lake

Cornwall’s largest lake, Colliford sits high on Bodmin Moor and offers spectacular fly fishing in a dramatic moorland setting. At over 900 acres, this reservoir provides challenging fishing for both wild brown trout and regularly stocked rainbow trout.

Fishing Information

Species: Rainbow trout (stocked), wild brown trout Methods: Fly fishing only Season: March to October (check current dates) Day Tickets: Available on site Facilities: Parking, toilet facilities, boat hire available

item.title: Hayle Estuary
item.description:
Hayle Estuary

The UK’s most southerly estuary and one of the few that never freezes, Hayle Estuary is managed by the RSPB and provides crucial habitat for wintering waders, waterfowl, and migrating birds.

Target Species

  • Spoonbill
  • Kingfisher
  • Purple Sandpiper
  • Iceland Gull
  • Caspian Gull
  • Great Northern Diver
  • Red-throated Diver
  • Black-throated Diver
  • Eider
  • Common Scoter
  • Various waders and wildfowl

Best Time to Visit

Winter months offer the best opportunities for observing divers, gulls, and winter waders. Morning sessions typically provide optimal viewing conditions.

item.title: Innis Fly Fishery
item.description:
Innis Fly Fishery

A well-established fly fishing venue near Bodmin, Innis Fly Fishery offers quality stillwater fishing in a more intimate setting than the large moorland reservoirs. The fishery is regularly stocked with quality rainbow and brown trout, providing consistent sport throughout the season.

Fishing Information

Species: Rainbow trout, brown trout Methods: Fly fishing only Season: Year-round (check for winter hours) Day Tickets: Available - advance booking recommended Facilities: On-site tackle shop, tuition available, parking, refreshments

item.title: Lower Tamar Lake
item.description:
Lower Tamar Lake

Situated on the Devon-Cornwall border near Bude, Lower Tamar Lake is a popular coarse fishing venue known for its quality carp fishing in a beautiful natural setting. The lake offers excellent opportunities for specimen hunters and pleasure anglers alike.

Fishing Information

Species: Carp (to over 20lb), roach, rudd, tench, bream, perch, pike Methods: All legal methods permitted Season: Year-round for most species (check pike season) Day Tickets: Available - some swims bookable in advance Facilities: Car parking, disabled access to some swims, toilets

item.title: Marazion Marsh
item.description:
Marazion Marsh

The RSPB’s most southerly reserve, Marazion Marsh provides crucial reedbed habitat for wetland birds. The reserve offers excellent viewing opportunities year-round with easy access and well-maintained paths.

Key Features

  • Extensive reedbeds
  • Open water areas
  • Viewing hides
  • Boardwalk access

Target Species

  • Reed Warbler (summer)
  • Sedge Warbler (summer)
  • Water Rail
  • Little Egret
  • Various duck species (winter)
  • Migrant waders
  • Kingfisher

Visiting Information

The reserve has good accessibility with level paths and viewing hides. Best visited early morning or late afternoon. Free entry as an RSPB reserve.

item.title: Meadow Lakes
item.description:
Meadow Lakes

A popular commercial fishery offering multiple well-stocked lakes catering to both pleasure anglers and specimen hunters. The venue provides consistent sport year-round with excellent facilities and a friendly, welcoming atmosphere.

Fishing Information

Species: Carp, tench, bream, roach, rudd, perch Methods: All legal coarse fishing methods permitted Season: Year-round Day Tickets: Available on site - no booking required for day tickets Facilities: On-site parking, tackle shop, refreshments, toilets, disabled access

item.title: Mounts Bay
item.description:
Mounts Bay

Mounts Bay provides superb coastal birding opportunities with excellent chances to observe winter sea ducks, divers, and grebes. The bay’s sheltered waters attract a variety of seabirds throughout the year.

Target Species

  • Great Northern Diver
  • Red-throated Diver
  • Black-throated Diver
  • Eider
  • Common Scoter
  • Purple Sandpiper
  • Slavonian Grebe
  • Red-breasted Merganser
  • Various gull species

Best Viewing Locations

The bay can be viewed from multiple points along the coast road between Penzance and Marazion. Morning sessions typically offer the best viewing conditions with good light and calmer seas.

item.title: Oakside Fishery
item.description:
Oakside Fishery

A purpose-built carp fishing venue offering quality fishing for specimen carp in a peaceful, well-maintained environment. Oakside provides excellent facilities for both day ticket anglers and those seeking longer sessions in pursuit of larger fish.

Fishing Information

Species: Carp (commons and mirrors), tench Methods: Hair rigs, boilies, pellets, particles - modern carp fishing methods Season: Year-round Day Tickets & Sessions: Day tickets and 24-hour sessions available - booking advised Facilities: Car parking, toilets, well-maintained swims, some with night fishing facilities

item.title: St Gothian Sands
item.description:
St Gothian Sands

A productive site on Cornwall’s north coast offering excellent opportunities for waders, gulls, and coastal birds. Part of popular birding routes combining with nearby Hayle Estuary.

Target Species

  • Short-eared Owl (winter)
  • Lapwing
  • Golden Plover
  • Iceland Gull (winter)
  • Glaucous Gull (winter)
  • Purple Sandpiper
  • Sanderling
  • Various wader species

Habitat

Sandy beach backed by dunes and grassland. The varied habitat attracts both coastal and terrestrial species, with the grassland areas particularly good for Short-eared Owls during winter.

item.title: The Camel Trail
item.description:
The Camel Trail

Distance: 18 miles (one way) | Type: Traffic-Free

Cornwall’s most famous cycling route, the Camel Trail follows a disused railway line for 18 miles from the historic fishing port of Padstow to Bodmin. This flat, traffic-free path is perfect for families and leisure cyclists of all abilities.

Route Overview

The trail runs along the picturesque Camel Estuary before heading inland through woodland and countryside to Bodmin. The entire route is on a well-maintained tarmac and hard-packed surface, making it suitable for all types of bikes including hybrids, road bikes, and mountain bikes.

item.title: The Cornish Way
item.description:
The Cornish Way

Distance: 180 miles | Type: National Cycle Network

The Cornish Way is Cornwall’s premier long-distance cycling route, forming part of the National Cycle Network. This epic journey runs from Land’s End to Bude on the Devon border, designed to avoid major roads while showcasing Cornwall’s finest landscapes, historic towns, fishing villages, and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty.

Route Overview

The route offers two alternative paths - one via Padstow on the North Cornish coast, the other via St Austell on the South coast - allowing cyclists to choose their preferred scenery or combine both for a complete Cornwall loop.

item.title: Upper Tamar Lake
item.description:
Upper Tamar Lake

Located adjacent to its larger sister water, Lower Tamar Lake, Upper Tamar offers a more intimate fishing experience in beautiful countryside on the Devon-Cornwall border. The lake provides both coarse fishing and trout fishing opportunities in a peaceful, scenic setting.

Fishing Information

Species: Rainbow trout, brown trout, carp, roach, rudd, tench, bream, perch, pike Methods: Fly fishing for trout, all legal methods for coarse species Season: Year-round (check specific species seasons) Day Tickets: Available on site Facilities: Car parking, toilets, some disabled access

item.title: Bodmin Moor Challenge
item.description:
Bodmin Moor Challenge

Distance: 40 miles | Difficulty: Hard | Type: Road

A challenging ride across dramatic Bodmin Moor with stunning views and significant climbing.

Highlights

  • Jamaica Inn - Historic coaching inn
  • Brown Willy - Highest point in Cornwall
  • Dramatic moorland scenery
  • Prehistoric sites and stone circles

Route Details

Starting Point: Launceston Terrain: Hilly with significant climbs Best Time: Summer (weather permitting) Estimated Time: 4-5 hours Elevation Gain: Approximately 800m

item.title: Brown Willy Summit
item.description:
Brown Willy Summit

Distance: 5 miles circular | Difficulty: Moderate | Duration: 3 hours

Climb Cornwall’s highest point (420m) for panoramic moorland views.

Highlights

  • Cornwall’s highest summit (420m/1,378ft)
  • 360-degree moorland views
  • Wild ponies and moorland wildlife
  • Bronze Age remains
  • Nearby Rough Tor (second highest)
  • Remote wilderness feel

Route Details

Starting Point: Rough Tor Car Park (PL15 7TF) Terrain: Moorland paths, rocky sections Best Time: Spring to Autumn (good weather) Elevation Gain: Approximately 250m OS Map: Explorer 109

item.title: Cornish Lanes Explorer
item.description:
Cornish Lanes Explorer

Distance: 15 miles | Difficulty: Easy | Type: Road

Perfect for families - quiet lanes through typical Cornish countryside.

Highlights

  • Traditional farms and countryside
  • Wildlife spotting
  • Peaceful narrow lanes
  • Village pubs for refreshments
  • Quintessential Cornwall scenery

Route Details

Starting Point: North Petherwin Terrain: Gentle rolling hills Best Time: Year-round Estimated Time: 1.5-2 hours Surface: Quiet country lanes

Description

This gentle route explores the classic Cornish landscape of narrow hedge-lined lanes, traditional farms, and small villages. Perfect for families or those wanting a relaxing ride without significant climbs. The route stays on quiet lanes with minimal traffic.

item.title: Crackington Haven
item.description:
Crackington Haven

Distance: 25 minutes (12 miles) | Level: Intermediate to Advanced | Type: Cove Beach, Reef Break

Beautiful cove with powerful waves when the swell is up - for experienced surfers.

Beach Overview

Crackington Haven is a stunning cove surrounded by dramatic cliffs. When conditions are right, it offers excellent surf, but the powerful waves and reef breaks make it better suited to experienced surfers. Less crowded than nearby Bude beaches.

item.title: Crackington Haven Coastal Walk
item.description:
Crackington Haven Coastal Walk

Distance: 8 miles circular | Difficulty: Moderate | Duration: 4 hours

One of Cornwall’s most dramatic coastal walks with spectacular cliff-top views and secluded coves.

Highlights

  • Towering coastal cliffs (over 400ft)
  • Crackington Haven beach
  • Secluded coves and rock formations
  • South West Coast Path section
  • Cambeak headland
  • Stunning sea views

Route Details

Starting Point: Crackington Haven Car Park (PL22 0PG) Terrain: Coastal path with steep sections Best Time: Year-round (avoid storms) Elevation Gain: Approximately 400m OS Map: Explorer 111

item.title: Golitha Falls
item.description:
Golitha Falls

Distance: 35 minutes | Type: River & Waterfalls | Difficulty: Moderate Access

Spectacular waterfall swimming in ancient woodland - one of Cornwall’s best wild swimming spots.

Overview

Golitha Falls is a series of spectacular waterfalls and pools on the River Fowey, set within ancient oak woodland. The crystal-clear pools beneath the waterfalls offer some of the most beautiful wild swimming in Cornwall. A magical spot that’s well worth the drive.

item.title: Launceston Loop
item.description:
Launceston Loop

Distance: 25 miles | Type: Road

A scenic circular route taking in the market town of Launceston and surrounding countryside.

  • Rolling countryside views
  • Quiet country lanes
  • Traditional Cornish villages

Description

This circular route starts from Waterloo Farm and takes you through beautiful Cornish countryside to the historic market town of Launceston. The route features quiet country lanes with occasional climbs offering rewarding views across the rolling landscape.

item.title: Summerleaze Beach & Sea Pool, Bude
item.description:
Summerleaze Beach & Sea Pool, Bude

Distance: 30 minutes | Type: Beach & Tidal Sea Pool | Difficulty: Easy

Unique tidal sea pool plus sandy beach - perfect for families and safe swimming.

Overview

Summerleaze is Bude’s main town beach, featuring the unique Bude Sea Pool - a tidal pool that fills with fresh seawater at high tide. This combination of sheltered pool swimming and open beach offers something for everyone, from young children to serious swimmers.

item.title: Tamar Valley Discovery Trail
item.description:
Tamar Valley Discovery Trail

Distance: 30 miles | Difficulty: Easy to Moderate | Type: Mixed

Follow the beautiful Tamar Valley through historic mining landscapes and riverside trails.

Highlights

  • River Tamar views
  • Mining heritage sites
  • Woodland trails
  • Gentle gradients
  • Wildlife spotting

Route Details

Starting Point: Launceston Terrain: Mostly flat with gentle hills Best Time: Year-round Estimated Time: 3-4 hours Surface: Mixed road and trail

Description

This scenic route follows the Tamar Valley, combining quiet lanes with sections of off-road trail. The Tamar Valley is an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty with rich mining heritage. The route is suitable for hybrid or mountain bikes due to mixed terrain.

item.title: Widemouth Bay
item.description:
Widemouth Bay

Distance: 20 minutes (12 miles) | Level: Beginner to Intermediate | Type: Sandy Beach Break

Perfect family beach with lifeguards and consistent waves for learning.

Beach Overview

Widemouth Bay is one of the best beaches in North Cornwall for learning to surf. The wide sandy beach offers consistent waves that work on most swells. Lifeguarded in summer and with surf schools operating, it’s ideal for beginners while still offering fun waves for intermediates.
